snippet: Giving to international organizations has fallen even as overall philanthropy has rebounded after the recession. What could make Americans give more to global causes?
abstract: Ron Lieber Your Money column observes that while overall level of philanthropy in America has exceeded its prerecession peak, giving to international causes has dropped off to mere 4 percent; observes that many people are reluctant to donate internationally, despite greater need abroad, due to lack of emotional connection and skepticism that money will be spent effectively; suggests target level of 25 percent.
lead_paragraph: Giving to international organizations has fallen even as overall philanthropy has rebounded after the recession. What could make Americans give more to global causes?

headline.print_headline: Giving More Globally, and Less Locally
